Section 1.[W 3281/1/98] No. 1.Lord Tyrrell to Sir John Simon. (Received April 7.)(No. 625.)HIS Majesty's representative at Paris presents his compliments to the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, and, with reference to Foreign Office telegram No. 68 of the 27th March, has the honour to transmit copy of a note from the French Ministry for Foreign Affairs respecting the disarmament question.Paris, April 6, 1934.Enclosure in No. 1.French Government's Note of April 6, 1934.LA note verbale remise le 28 mars au Ministere des Affaires etrangeres par le premier Secretaire de PAmbassade d'Angleterre a retenu Pattention la plus serieuse du Gouvernement de la Republique. II n'a pas manque, par ailleurs, d'etre profondement sensible aux commentaires dont a bien voulu 1'accompagner, des le lendemain, son Excellence Lord Tyrrell dans Pentrevue qu'il a issue avec le Ministre.II faut tout d'abord remarquer que la reponse demandee au Gouvernement frangais est une reponse de principe, pour le cas ou les circonstances permettraient la realisation de deux hypotheses, qui restent, cependant, entierement a verifier :(1) Hypothese d'une solution generale ou regionale du probleme des garanties d'execution, ayant pour objet de fixer les limites d'armements dans des conditions assurant Pentiere securite des signataires de la convention.(2) Hypothese d'une conventibn satisfaisante sur la base d'un rearmemenf, limite et controle, des Etats lies jusqu'ici par les clauses militaires des traites de paix. Quand une Puissance aurait obtenu cette revision de ses engagements, on voit mai comment le benefice pourrait en etre refuse a cPautres.Ce point de depart d'une convention nouvelle romprait avec toutes les regies essentielles qui n'ont pas cesse d'inspirer et de guider tous les travaux de la Conference du Desarmement.Le Gouvernement de la Republique serait heureux de pouvoir donner la reponse sollicitee par le Gouvernement de Sa Majeste, s'il n'avait le sentiment profond qu'une semblable solution Pengagerait dans des principes differents de ceux auxquels il entend rester fidele aussi longtemps que la conference s'associera a sa volonte et a son espoir de signer une convention, congue dans 1'esprit de Particle 8 du Pacte et en harmonie avec le preambule de la Partie V du Traite de Versailles.II faut rappeler que la note frangaise du 17 mars, a laquelle se reference PAmbassadeur d'Angle ter re, declarait que: " Seule la Commission, generale pourrait dire, avec la participation des Etats interesses, si ces principes qui ont, jusqu'ici, guide ses travaux doivent etre abandonn^s." La meme note ajoutait:. "Si elles etaient degagees des obligations juridiques qu'elles ont souscrites, les Puissances ne prendraient en consideration, pour se determiner, que leurs interets directs." Cette derniere consideration implique qu'avant de se prononcer sur la question posee par PAmbassadeur d'Angleterre, la France serait fondee a elucider les divers aspects des deux hypotheses dont cette question derive, et que les communications qui lui ont ete faites n'ont pas permis de degager jusqu'ici d'une maniere sufnsante.[86 g-1] Pourtant, fidele a 1'amitie qui le lie au peuple britannique, le Gouvernement de la Republique tient a ajouter qu'a cote des interets directs de la France, il a une trop haute conscience des devoirs que la collaboration internationale impose aux deux pays, pour ne pas repondre, d'une maniere positive, a une demarche de 1'Ambassadeur dAngleterre qui a ete un nouveau et vivant temoignage de cette amitie.Cest dans un tel esprit que, sous la reserve d'une reponse de principe qu'il appartient a la seule Commission generale de donner, il est pret a poursuivre avec le Gouvernement britannique un change de vues dont il reconnait toute 1'impor-tance et dont il attend les plus heureux resultats.Au point oil en sont les conversations engagees, le Gouvernement de la Republique ne peut pas repondre qu'il accepte le memorandum du Royaume-Uni du 29 Janvier, avec les modifications qui 1'ont suivi, pour base dune convention oil entreraient de nouvelles garanties d'execution. Cette adhesion, trop gen^rale pour n'etre pas equivoque, ne tiendrait pas compte de trop de questions de 1'ordre technique et de 1'ordre politique, qui sont encore en suspens, et qu'il ne suffit pas d'avoir posees pour les tenir pour resolues.Aussi le Gouvernement de la Republique adressera-t-il, a bref delai, a FAmbassadeur les eclaircissements qu'il a sollicites sur la conception francaise des garanties d'execution. D'autre part, il lui fera parvenir diverses demandes de renseignements, en particulier sur des points que la note verbale du 28 mars a indiques dans ses dernieres lignes, mais qu'elle n'a pas precises.La France reste fidele a 1'oeuvre que la Conference du Desarmement poursuit depuis deux ans. Elle lui a apporte une collaboration active, qu'il n'a pas dependu d'elle de rendre plus efficace et d'acheminer vers une solution definitive. II lui repugnerait de paraitre entraver, ou meme simplement retarder son succes. Mais, a 1'heure ou certains budgets accusent, par des chiffres officiels, une augmentation des armements limites par les traites, elle a, une fois de plus, le souci d'accorder avec sa volonte de paix les besoins d'une s&urite' dont elle sait le plus grand gre au Gouvernement britannique de rechercher avec elle les conditions et les garanties.L. B.Paris, le 6 avril 1934.(Translation.)THE note handed on the 28th March to the Ministry for Foreign Affairs by the first secretary of the British Embassy has been studied with the closest attention by the Government of the Republic. It has not failed also to take into full account the comments with which his Excellency Lord Tyrrell was good enough to accompany it in the interview which he had on the following day with the Minister.2. It should first of all be noted that the reply which is required of the French Government is a reply of principle, based on the assumption that circum-stances would permit the realisation of two suppositions which have, however, yet to be examined : (1) Supposition that a general or regional solution is found for the problem of the guarantees of execution with the object of fixing a limitation of armaments in conditions which would assure the complete security of the signatories of the convention.(2) Supposition that a satisfactory convention can be reached on the basis of a limited and supervised rearmament of the States hitherto bound by the military clauses of the Treaties of Peace. When one Power has obtained the revision of its obligations in this respect it is difficult to see how it could be refused to others.3. This starting-point for a new convention would break away from all the essential rules which have continuously inspired and guided the whole work of the Disarmament Conference.4. The Government of the Republic would be glad to be able to give the reply asked for by His Majesty's Government, did it not feel profoundly that such a solution would commit it to principles differing from those to which it is determined to adhere so long as the conference wishes and hopes for the signature of a convention conceived in the spirit of article 8 of the Covenant and in harmony with the preamble of Part V of the Treaty of Versailles. 5.' It must be remembered that the French note of the 17th March to which the British Ambassador refers declared that: '' Only the General Commission with the participation of all the interested States is able to say whether these principles which have guided its work up to now should be abandoned." The same note added : "If they were liberated from the juridical obligations to which they have subscribed, the Powers would only take into consideration their direct interests in determining their actions." This latter consideration means that before pronouncing itself on the question raised by the British Ambassador, France is justified in elucidating the various aspects of the two suppositions out of which this question arises, and which the communications addressed up to date have not made it possible to establish sufficiently clearly.6. However, faithful to the friendship by which it is bound to the British people, the Government of the Republic wishes to add that, apart from the direct interests of France, it is too deeply conscious of the duties which international collaboration imposes on the two countries not to reply in a positive manner to a demarche of the British Ambassador which was a new and living token of this friendship.7. It is in this spirit that, under reserve of a reply in principle which only the General Commission is competent to give, the French Government is ready to enter with the British Government upon an exchange of views of which it recognises the great importance and from which it expects the most happy results.8. At the stage which the present conversations have reached, the Government of the Republic cannot reply that it accepts the United Kingdom memorandum of the 29th January with the modifications which have followed it as the basis of a convention which would contain new guarantees of execution. Such an acceptance would be too general not to be open to misunderstanding, and would take no account of too many problems of a technical and political nature which are still in suspense, and which it is not sufficient to have raised in order to consider them resolved.9. The Government of the Republic, therefore, will shortly furnish the Ambassador with the explanations for which he has asked on the French conception of the guarantees of execution. In addition, it will also transmit a number of requests for information, in particular on certain points which were indicated in the closing lines of the note of the 28th March, but which were not given in detail.10. France remains faithful to the work which the Disarmament Conference has been undertaking for two years. She has given her active collaboration, and it is not her fault if it has not been made more efficacious and has not led to a definite solution. She would feel reluctant to appear to hinder or even to retard its success. But at a moment when certain budgets show in the official figures an increase in the armaments limited by the treaties, France is once more concerned to reconcile with her desire for peace the needs of security, and she is most grateful to the British Government for seeking with her the necessary conditions and guarantees of such security.Paris, A pril 6, 1934.
